151412430.review:
一代的VR三个头显都买了，但画质和游戏那会儿都不行，而需要转圈的游戏，有线VR又会绊倒。几个月过后基本除了偶尔玩玩BeatSaber就再也不碰VR了。今年换了无线头显，赶紧趁假期补神作，这不愧是卖Index的招牌游戏，真没得说。画面比想象中好很多，操作很舒服的，代入感很强，这几天就是打俩小时，充电俩小时，轮番肝三天通关了。这做游戏还得看V社啊。可惜的是HL系列更新速度人尽皆知，剧情都忘记得差不多了。。。

每次玩HL不得不吐槽的是最烦的猎头蟹，哪个家伙想出来的太恶心了，但至少没有放在开箱子的时候。VR可以瞬移，对付猎头蟹和狮蚁的围攻其实反而要好周旋很多。然而瞄准相对难些，尤其是有激光之前用物理瞄具，精确射击的姿势局限很大，摆枪也影响视野和反应速度。

唯一的小问题就是自动提升分辨率的逻辑似乎没有考虑到显存大小，40系列（除了4090）运算相比显存失衡了，加上现在头显的分辨率本身就不低，默认设置就会导致游戏在不那么复杂的场景自动拉高分辨率，本来就4K了硬拉到双倍，经常就是爆了显存然后狂卡和奔溃。留一个命令行免得重装了忘记，这个至少在我的4070Ti上跑Ultra就没问题了。当然最好下一代显存别挤牙膏了，就用不着这个了。

-nowindow -novid -console -vconsole +vr_fidelity_level_auto 0 +vr_fidelity_level 3 +vr_render_scale 1.0

150464902.review:
an excellent half life game.

just like a lot of people, i waited long years for this one. always suspected its gonna be VR when it comes, but i never expected what they really did after all.

the storytelling and immersion in this game are surreal. its absurd how real the experience feels all aspects combined.
the touch and feel of it is just out of this world. so are the physics. and both artistically and graphically i think that no VR game comes even close as of late 2023. overall this is propably one of the best games i have ever played in general. the feel of its environmental storytelling is beyond words. even though this is primarily a linear game, the once in a while replay value hits hard. you can toy around with the mechanics and physics for ages. or just walk around looking at the world taking everything in piece by piece. or just experimenting with different combat moves and strategies in its sandbox-y shooter environment with lovely puzzles. what i appreciate most is that it does something much smarter than just continuing the cliff hanger we got in EP2. now i try to write my reviews as spoiler free as possible. im the kinda guy who barely watches trailers and likes to go in for surprises more often than not. but what i can tell you while being non specific is that this game does something much more interesting and puzzling with the narrative than just continue where we left of. at first it seems like a not so related prequel to half life 2 but later on the connection gets seriously intense to say the least. some of its own ends are closed here but i absolutely cannot wait to find out what happens next. also make sure you DO play at the very least half life 2 and episodes 1 and 2 before you go into HL ALYX. ideally also half life 1. they are incredible games that all play like they came out yesterday so if you somehow still didnt play them, knock youurself out.
cheers.

while part of this titles purpose is a game being experienced in a completely revolutionary way, there is another purpose it serves for the greater franchise as a whole. and that is an evolutionary one. and it serves that purpose with love, care and determination. this game sets a beautiful stage for possible endeavors into the half life portal universe. and ill be waiting eager as ever.

thank you valve for your dedication to this amazing franchise and always keeping up with your incredibly high quality standards. your games continue to entice and inspire and i believe this release shows that it can be worth it to be patient and wait in ease for something really great.

gg

150379843.review:
Half-Life: Alyx is nothing short of a triumph in the realm of virtual reality gaming. Developed by Valve Corporation, this installment in the iconic Half-Life series has set a new standard for immersive gameplay and storytelling within the VR landscape.

Graphics and Immersion: 5/5
The visual fidelity of Half-Life: Alyx is nothing short of breathtaking. From the intricate details of the environment to the lifelike character animations, every aspect of the game is designed to draw players into the dystopian world of City 17. The Source 2 engine truly shines, delivering an unparalleled level of realism that enhances the overall immersion.

Gameplay: 4.5/5
The gameplay mechanics of Half-Life: Alyx are a testament to the potential of VR gaming. The intuitive controls, precise interactions, and realistic physics create an experience that feels both natural and responsive. The game cleverly integrates VR features, requiring players to physically reach for items, solve puzzles, and engage in combat with a level of tactility that traditional gaming can't match.

Story and Atmosphere: 4.5/5
True to the legacy of the Half-Life series, Alyx doesn't disappoint in terms of narrative depth and atmosphere. The storytelling is engaging, weaving seamlessly into the existing lore while introducing new characters and plot twists. The oppressive ambiance of City 17 is palpable, and the game succeeds in maintaining a sense of tension throughout the entire experience.

Sound Design: 5/5
The audio in Half-Life: Alyx is a standout feature, contributing significantly to the overall atmosphere. From the haunting echoes of distant Combine chatter to the subtle creaking of dilapidated buildings, every sound is meticulously crafted. The use of 3D audio technology further enhances the sense of space and directionality, adding another layer to the immersive experience.

VR Innovation: 5/5
Half-Life: Alyx pushes the boundaries of what VR can achieve. It not only demonstrates the potential for narrative-driven VR games but also serves as a showcase for innovative design and interaction possibilities within the medium. The game sets a new standard for VR titles and has undoubtedly paved the way for future developments in the industry.

Half-Life: Alyx is a tour de force in virtual reality gaming. It successfully marries the rich storytelling of the Half-Life universe with the immersive capabilities of VR technology. While the need for VR hardware might limit accessibility for some, those with the means to experience it will find themselves transported into one of the most compelling and memorable gaming experiences of recent years. Valve has not only revived a beloved franchise but has also redefined the expectations for what is possible in the realm of virtual reality gaming.

Not gonna lie: first time when I played this game, I understood what Half-Life and other projects mean for Valve. 

It means to them technological revolution at all means. 
Remember HL1 when it first released? Lots of voices around the world told the same thing: it's a revolution!
What about HL2? They introduced Source engine with the best physics possible at the moment. 

The game is not that much about the plot, although the storytelling is amazing...

Simply switching to Source 2 and delivering standard PC experience wouldn't revolutionize gaming. 
But using other delivery methods with fully-immersive environment and one of the best graphic possibilities - that's the revolution and the push to the world of widely known PCVR gaming.

Valve, in general, is a company that opens the door to the future of diversified gaming. When they delivered Steam to us, great physics, Steam controller (although it's a failure from business point, the controller is great), Index helmet, Deck. 

I think with their passion to the revolution and novation, they will be the first ones who will make full support of Neuralink in Dota...

149892774.review:
First and foremost, I think this is the most polished VR game ever made. It's not a cut-down experience made to work with VR, it's a full-fledged VR game. Unfortunately, so many years in, that's still the case. There are some issues with weapon handling that could be improved, but a lot of that comes down to bulky and inaccurate controllers.

As for the negatives, I'm not a fan of ammo-scarcity in games, and this game has a TON of it. Weapons don't seem to have enough power to taken anything down without hitting very small hit boxes (again, bulky and inaccurate controllers), so I find myself using a lot more ammo than I would otherwise. And when you do find ammo, it's one mag here, two shotgun shells there, etc. Occasionally, you'll find an ammo box, but that usually means you're about to fight a bunch of enemies, so you'll be out again soon.

The biggest issue I have is with performance. Every so often after the game loads I'll drop down to 10fps, and nothing seems to get it to go back to normal. I'll have to completely shut everything down and start it back up again. Also, even worse, sometimes the game will completely lock up my entire computer to the extent that I have to hard reset. It's the only VR game I have this issue with, and it's a very serious issue. I don't want to have to worry about data corruption every time I run a game.

Then I realized I had only been playing for an hour, and I had an entire game ahead of me. Every single minute is a blast and even after several years there is still no other VR title that comes close to being this fun. Flicking grenades around corners, using your gun to bust out a window before you start shooting, going prone with a minigun whizzing over your head, everything here feels like the most fun you've ever had. And I didn't even get to the optional stuff like the minigames which are extremely creative (except the red lines sphere I fucking hate it.) 10/10 #justiceforjeff

149610309.review:
[Nov 2023 SteamVR2.0 + Virtual Desktop issue?]
I'll explain at the top of this, I can't seem to play through Alyx on Virtual Desktop without SteamVR crashing. It's the only game that does this in my Steam library. Reloading a checkpoint or loading a new chapter causes freezing on the loading view and forces me to just stop entirely. I haven't played more than 10 minutes since SteamVR's 2.0 update

-----

[Meta Quest 3 + Virtual Desktop | 3060TI/i5 9600k]
3070 Graphic Settings + HEVC 10 bit Encoding + 200mbps
I get around 45-50mbps Latency which is my usual, a little stuttering with multiple enemies on the field but not a major drawback as the HEVC 10 bit Encoding provides much more colour accuracy at the cost of this, otherwise use HEVC and have fun

[Half-Life: Alyx]
I've not really played Half-Life, closest i've come is Portal so i'm not unfamiliar with the games feel. 

Believe it or not, but I too am one of those "Its the best VR game ever" people, seriously even in 2023 and without playing the latest VR titles I know this is S tier. It really provides the full action-rpg experience i'd expect from a large studio, and is definitely a feel of Half-Life in the newer age
There's very little bad to say about the core game, it provides most VR options and has thought through a lot of the ways this game can be experienced

Game wise its a simple-ish action game, from tense dark scenes to grand almost cut scene level visuals all in VR which is very impressive and just like VR, very difficult to explain without "being there"
It's also one of the longest VR games i've played really (around 10 - 15 hours YMMV). Other VR games are 30mins - 1hr of either roguelike rounds or just the full experience, and i'm tired of that. 

With Half-Life Alyx I can really see in the right hardware going for full sessions of 4+ hours, and I can see with the Quest 3 + hardware accessories, you could really get there

If there's only up from here we're in for a good time!

148831910.review:
Half-Life: Alyx Review: Out of Ammo, But Not Out of Fun!

Ladies and gentlemen, dust off your VR headsets and prepare for a trip to the not-so-distant future where ammo is apparently more precious than toilet paper in a pandemic! Introducing Half-Life: Alyx, the game where you constantly feel like you're on a desperate scavenger hunt for bullets. And no, it's not Half-Life 3, so let's just get that out of the way before someone starts a rumor!

In this thrilling VR escapade, you'll be facing off against adversaries, only to look down and realize: "Wait, where did all my ammo go?!" You defeat them, only to run low again. And then you move on, triumphantly... and yep, you guessed it, you're out of ammo. Again. Makes you wonder if the game secretly doubled as a rationing lesson. (I swear I wasn't trying to shoot stars out of the sky, but a gamer can dream, right?)

But don't let the sporadic scarcity of bullets fool you. The graphics? Immaculate. The gameplay? Seamless. The feeling of desperately searching for ammo while an alien is chasing you? Priceless. Or should I say... bulletless?

If you've ever wanted to experience what it's like to be both awed and mildly irritated at the same time, then Half-Life: Alyx is the game for you. The VR mechanics are spot on, and aside from occasionally wanting to scream, "WHERE IS THE AMMO?!", you're in for an authentic and enthralling Half-Life adventure. Dive in, but maybe keep a backup slingshot handy, just in case. 😉

148728271.review:
After leaching off of a friend's tech, I recently decided to stop being broke and invested in a VR headset to see what all the fuss was about. What better game to really sink my teeth into other than Valve's foray into a full-length VR experience? Well I can hardly think of a better example, this game is fantastic. I have little experience with VR so I'm not sure how to describe it, but the combat and exploration in this game is immersive and really fun. The levels, weapons, random items to mess with, and enemies all interact and look exactly how you think it would FEEL. I cannot praise the attention to detail enough.

Yet despite this, Half-life Alyx manages to still be very accessible with different movement options, simple weapon mechanics, and no weird inventory fiddling. If you have any experience with video games, I could totally recommend this as your first large VR game and I think you'd find it easy enough to get into. Actually, that's maybe the biggest praise I could give HLA. Even if this game wasn't VR, I still would've enjoyed it a ton. That's not something I think can be said about most VR games.

148726281.review: The killer app for VR. Welcome back to city 17

148714294.review:
This game is fantastic, one of, if not, the best VR shooter, Hell, VR game ever made. Graphics are incredible with the fancy Source 2 engine, displaying highly detailed character models with impressive facial animation. Physics have been improved greatly, being able to fully show the realistic weight of certain objects. And while certain beloved characters such as Barney and Kleiner don't make a return, we're introduced to a British chap named Russel, who's still as enjoyable as those we've seen in Half Life 2. Plus, and this isn't a spoiler, but it expands on the story despite being a prequel :)
My only gripes with the game is that it's incredibly laggy on slightly lower-end systems, and you'd need the Valve Index to truly experience this game to it's fullest. And while it does make sense to have it be geared for extremely high-end systems and build the game off of the headset your company made, it's frustrating to have to know what graphics card you need to run the game on just the lowest settings and not be bombarded with lagspikes. I use a GTX 1070 on 32 gigs of ram with the Oculus Rift S and can barely get an extremely clear, smooth image.
But despite those, I love this game. It's one of the last games to fully revolutionize gaming as we've reached our limit at this point. Can't wait to see what Half Life 3 will have to offer once we get to that point. Valve isn't very well-known for making games in a small timeframe, but that just shows their dedication. We had almost a whole decade of nothing but updates for Team Fortress 2 and CS:GO. And seeing how they treated TF2 after Jungle Inferno, it's best to assume we have a lot to look forward to in the rest of this decade.

Still by far the best VR game released (at least that I have played) and truly the benchmark for what makes a good VR implementation. The graphics are amazing, the movement options are great, and you can pickup or interact with almost everything. You can even see the liquid in bottles and it behaves as you'd expect, and if you throw a bottle it will smash. These all seem like silly things to comment on, but it's so far ahead of what most other games will do and really lends to the immersion.

Most importantly, this is an actual AAA VR game with a good story and reasonable play time (for once, a game that isn't just a glorified tech demo). On top of that, they have a built in workshop that allow you to play loads of user created mods, some of which are whole games unto themselves! If you have a VR headset and haven't played this yet, what are you waiting for????

148182605.review: Once again Half Life has gone and done something amazing.  Somehow, Alyx has succeeded in nearly every aspect I've ever wanted from a VR FPS.  The combat is clean and the guns feel crisp.  The environments are well designed and enjoyable to play.  It would feel great even in 2D.  But as a VR game it really showcases the Half Life series ability to up the game in insane ways.  Source physics have become almost sane, and somehow this game has some of the best graphics in VR while still being able to run on fairly light hardware.  My only large complaint is the lack of melee, but considering how much VR melee combat tends to feel like swinging noodles around in syrup, I think loosing it is overall the right choice.

148018693.review:
[i] Weeks will pass, but the feeling of holding tight to the dear gnome will remain... [/i]

[h3] Introduction [/h3]
To this day, hands down the best PCVR experience the money can buy. Even if you are not familiar with the Half-Life franchise, give it a chance; you will unlikely be disappointed. If you care deeply about the performance aspect and worry if your setup can handle it - the game is highly optimized and rarely causes any frame drops. After all, a refund is always a possibility. The trailer will never do it for you in the same way the game could.

[h3] Story & World Building [/h3]
All the details within make this world feel truly alive, unlike any other VR environment that looks fake at a glance. The pure quality of assets used and clever level design together play a great role in immersing you as a player. The narrative is delivered seamlessly; you are always present in the world, and it actually responds to your actions. Intensive scenes are executed perfectly, and the VR itself adds much more depth than you can ever imagine.

[h3] Compatibility Concerns [/h3]
Being originally designed to showcase the true spectrum of VR interactions Index is capable of, the game holds well when it comes to other headsets and conrollers. Unique features like squeezing the palm of your hand while holding an object were simply rebinded to an action button within your reach. It means that regardless of your current VR setup, the game will adapt and provide as much content as it can without leaving some of it behind.

[h3] Conclusion & Final Notes [/h3]
The magnitude of hard work and dedication that the Valve team put in when making this game can never be expressed enough. It is a unique, mesmerizing, and engaging experience that will last you hours upon hours and will still be able to surprise you, catch you off guard. Words don't do justice at this point, and if you made it this far - treat yourself and explore the world of Half-Life: Alyx to its fullest.

[Note Finished the game with the NO-VR Mod]  

Worth the wait for the most part. A stunning return to one of my favourite universes. Some truly god-like design and world building; driven by a fun engaging cast. Seriously the voice work here is fantastic. It even expands on ideas that never really got explored in HL2. 

Do know going in, it plays a lot more like a survival horror game crossed with a walking sim than the rest of Half Life; and the combine soldiers; while having a superb visual rework are kind of dumb as bricks.  

It does admittingly play it a little safe at points; the monster variety is good but limited; There's only 4 weapons, pacing is excellent but and it could be gone for a few more hours IMO.  

The No-VR mod is damn good for what it it's; yes, it is very janky and crashes at points, but the pure half-life experience is faithfully maintained. Immense credit to the Mod developers for giving many who cannot financially or medically afford to buy what is still just a piece of gimmick tech a chance to experience this game. It’s also super easy to install. 

Highly Recommend  

8/10

147198003.review:
Summary
HA Alyx is good. The campaign is 15-ish hours long. This game is not worth the normal price that is like 70e. I got the game when it was at the 66% sale. Which cost me like 20e. The campaign is good, with good, simple puzzels and physics. But the combat is lacking. It is very slow, most of the time youll be ducking behind cover, waiting for the enemies to be done shooting. Yes, this is exactly how the CoD does it. But this is a VR game. You use your whole body to do physical things. Like boneworks. You can use meele weapons to kill enemies. The Graphics are phenomenal, these graphisc are the best to this date. And finally mods, they are fine. Theyll keep you enganged until you get bored of the slow combat.

Now to the longer explenation

Campaing
I completed the game with around 16 hours. Its a good campaign. It shows of new things almost every level. There arent really any specific levels i didint enjoy. Maybe the later levels because my game was lagging, due to my PC specs. To put it simply, a normal valve campaign, but. Even when the game shows of new things like new enemy types, controls, physics, puzzels and all that. It all is nothing new. Its things we've seen before. No new physics or mechanics. Maybe on thing i really think is cool about the game that i havent seen any other VR game do is that Alyx's hands react to what you are touching, not holding. If you for an example put your hand on a slope. Youll see that her fingers react and follow the pattern/slope. But thats just a visual thing. It doesnt change the gameplay. 

Combat/Gameplay
The gameplay as mentioned before ,its slow. HIde, shoot, hide, shoot. There isnt really a lot of variety to kill enemies. It really goes down to shooting until they die or throw a grenade. A lot of people say this game is good but isnt nothing new or special. Which is true. Best example i can give is Boneworks. A lot of variety of guns, meeles and with faster combat. There are mods to fix that like the sprint mod. But HA Alyx wanst made for that. It was made to be slow paced combat. Where you hide behind cover to start blasting the enemies after they have run out of ammo. The only thing i will remember HA Alyx for is the graphics, speaking of graphics. 

Grapics
The graphics are the BEST i have EVER SEEN. My pc couldnt handle the big open areas soo i had to lower the graphics down to low in the settings. And yet it looked phenomenal. Truly the greatest looking VR game to this date. It alos runs pretty smooth. I also had to turn of any background things like spotify, operaGX, steam and soo on, soo that my game wouldnt lag (My PC is a mid-spec or whatever you call it) Overall the graphics were REALLY GOOD. Even when i lowered them the the lowest setting i could it ran pretty smooth. Only the later levels were laggy.

Mods
I have tried a few mods like the bioshock campaings, the continetal map and a few gun replacment mod. They were all good. Thats all i can say about mods since i only have 23 hours.

146792761.review:
--- NO-VR-MOD review (Work in progress)

I've played like 2/3rds of Alyx on a friends HTC Vive (IIRC), so I know what Alyx is like in VR and It was great!!
But I cannot last longer for like 1 hour at  a time,  because the headset gets too stressful for my neck and it's mentally so much more demanding for me  than 'flatscreen'-games.

---NON-VR-PERFORMANCE
 -- WINDOWS

Then the No-VR-Mod came along (currently V0.9 installer). Under Windows 10 it works great on my RX 7600. The game is playable at HIGH and ULTRA setings at stable 60Hz (probably more but my TFT does not support more FPS).
The Mod turns Alyx in a most seemless NON-VR FPS game. Only issues I had were some minor input-recognition issues on game elements specifically designed for 3D manipulation. 

 -- LINUX
 - PROTON (non-native Linux version)
Under Linux (Ubuntu 23.04) manual installation of the MOD worked only partially for me (no 'Mouse Pointer'/  strange Pointer offset), so I just copied the game files from Windows over into my Linux Steam-library and it worked as expected.
But the performance under Linux is not so good, even with Vulkan. On WIndows 10 I got no problems running with HIGH Performance settings, under Linux I get some unstable 40 to 60 FPS in LOW settings and some more minor loading hiccups (no pop-ins).

- NATIVE LINUX VERSION
I don"t get the menu at the start of the game, so - no show I am afraid.

--- CONCLUSION
So, for all you without Headsets: You can safely enjoy Alyx in non-VR. It's still downright awesome.
Just download the installer and off you go!

146750932.review:
A game that I can very clearly see the reasons literally everyone recommended it to me as the first VR game I try.

The game had a lot of fun, really interesting reactions with objects in-game reacting to the world as you'd expect them to. Feeding the little alien rat and drawing phalluses on the whiteboard were pretty much my first indications that I was going to have a good time. Although this type of object reaction doesn't exist in the same amount of detail as the first 2 hours of the game, the times where it continued this trend were truly goofy.

The gunplay was really cool. Though it took a while to get used to as a first VR game, and I learned very early on that saves are your friend for when things go wrong (not very often I have to say this with shooters tbh). Each gun has its own upgrades and styles of reloading that you had to physically reload. It had a perfect balance of immersion and gameplay feel in those aspects. It felt like my ammo was considerably lower at the start of the game, but was then in abundance toward the end. Or maybe I just got better at the game honestly.

Not really into the whole Half-Life lore, the only game I really played extensively was HL-1. But even despite that, Rhys Darby in my ear as Russel made the whole thing a little more lighthearted juxtaposed against the entire world being taken over by the combine. The twist ending was also really good, and made even someone who doesn't care about the lore soyface at their little ending twist. Valve is very good at setting up cliffhanger endings and then never releasing a game afterwards, and they do that really well here too.

All in all though definitely recommend it, as a VR vet or someone who hasn't played VR before in their life. Game is well optimised, had little to no framerate issues, and one of the few games I tried in VR that didn't make me feel like throwing up.

Simply the best VR game ever made. I knew before I played it that it had that reputation. It didn't disappoint. The only thing that is extremely upsetting is that there aren't more games of this calibur. It was well worth the investment IMO. I wanted to play this, I had a very outdated computer. I spent $3000 on a prebuilt Skytech prism and $400 on a quest 2. Best entertainment investment I have made.
The level of detail is so impressive. I spent many hours just looking around and appreciating the tiny details. I small can of bug spray, when you hold it to your face and read the tiny print, you can see the ingridients and warnings etc. Everything a real can would have.
The single most impressive thing is the physics. I put a spoon into a teacup. it stood up. i put another one on the other side and it also stood up. then i put both spoons on the same side and the cup tipped over. it sounds like an irrelevant thing, but it says so much about the realism in the physics. The gun fights are so fun. Ducking down and laying on my living room floor to hide behind obstacles in the game was very OP and very satisfying.

146216844.review:
Although this game isn't exactly new any more, and although VR tech has progressed since the time it was released, and although it may be not quite long enough, and although it may be a bit strange as a Half-Life game... Alyx is quite simply the best VR and immersive FPS and/or RPG experience of the last ten years. Playing this game brings the excitement of playing your first RPG right back to you through the lens of VR and an impressively realistic world. It may not be perfect, but its shortcomings are insignificant when compared to the holes in most other VR titles, and the dialogue, graphics, and slow but heart-racing gameplay make up for the rest.

Alyx is a risk worth taking, and only leaves you wanting more VR content - anything really - produced by professional teams. Right now a lot of VR content consists of either buggy WIPs drawn out for Patreon money or user content-based sandboxes, so let us just hope that Valve and other AAA studios decide to move away from regenerated copy-paste status quo profit bait and into more interesting, immersive experiences like this.

146076795.review:
Half Life is my all time favorite IP and series, and I'm happy to say I enjoyed Half Life: Alyx. I didn't agree with every creative decision that Valve took with this game, but overall I'm super happy to see Half Life return and I can't wait for newer games in the series.
The gameplay was amazing. All of it is incredibly fun and has Valve's characteristic high level of quality when it comes to level design, puzzles, enemy design. Having to actually manually reload guns and throw grenades adds a unique feel to the game that makes even headcrabs and zombies a legitimate challenge. The Combine especially are a much bigger challenge and have some of the most realistic behavior and tactics I've seen - they really feel like you're fighting actual soldiers. Jeff was a fantastic horror segment, truly a proud successor to Ravenholm. I just love the whole "fungal zombies" idea, so getting some of that in Half Life is just *chef's kiss.*
The story overall was great, it fit well into the HL storyline. As for the ending, [spoiler]at first I was a bit upset about Gman just changing the established timeline so Eli survives, I'm honestly not a fan of that trope. But honestly, the ending doesn't really show anything the Gman hasn't already been shown or implied to be capable of. [/spoiler]
The atmosphere and creative design is where I have a few issues. Everything seems a lot flashier and over-engineered than in previous Half Life games: examples like how the Manhacks glow, all the little bitty moving parts in the Combine charging stations, how a lot of characters have more over the top, exaggerated mannerisms, little stuff like that. Almost feels a bit more like Dishonored - it's not a bad aesthetic at all but I think in the future Valve should steer more towards the Half Life 2 monolithic aespects of the Combine. Not all of it is bad of course; at first I didn't like the new Combine designs but they've really grown on me. Also the humor, to be honest I think some of the humor was overdone, especially for a universe as dark as Half Life. Again, this is all nitpicking, the game still has tons of great charm and excellent little details that I truly appreciate. I think one thing that sort of threw me off was the Source 2 engine; I'm so used to Source 1 that the game almost looked not surreal enough for me lmao - this is just something I'll need to get used to, not a fault of the game at all, and the game is absolutely GORGEOUS, especially at dawn, this game is stunningly beautiful.
The soundtrack, to be honest, I was disappointed by. There were some great tracks, the track for the final Strider battle and the ending credits music were fantastic and fit perfectly. But other than that, the soundtrack was pretty generic, it seemed like something more out of Doom and Hollywood than Half Life 2's pretty distinctive sound.
Overall, I give Half Life: Alyx an 80/100. I'm so, so happy that we got a new Half Life game after all these years, and I can't wait to see what the future of my favorite franchise holds. It's clear that regardless of some aspects of HLA I didn't really like, there's a ton of love and hard work in this game and I appreciate every bit of it. Hopefully a standard PC port comes soon so everybody gets a chance to play this game.

145719891.review:
Despite the hype and the tremendous amount of expectations valve had to deal with at the release of Half-Life Alyx, I'm amazed to say this game lives up to it all. 

An absolute achievement in VR gaming and VR storytelling and a landmark few have come close to surpassing even 3 years later. The combat, the enemies and the environments are all superb. Combat is not as fast as the two previous entries in the series but it makes up for that with much more tactical and methodical gameplay, where every shot matters and positioning is key. 

It's not a perfect experience though, and all my issues come from the fact Valve were afraid not to scare any newcomers off of VR. We lack sprinting, instead of that we can teleport for faster movement, which surprisingly works well. The teleport ability also replaces jumping, but that does not work nearly as nicely as it did for sprinting. 

The arsenal is also very limited as we have only 3 weapons this time. And again in fear of scaring off newcomers we don't have any two handed weapons and no melee combat. None of these issues are deal-breakers since the game is build around all this in mind. The ability to upgrade guns also goes a long way to make up for the limited arsenal.
I do wish they updated the game to add more movement options now that the game has been out for a few years. 

The only real problem with Half-Life Alyx is valve's insistence on not releasing a proper SDK for the game to allow modders to go wild. As we speak there are quite a few good mods and maps, but we won't be seeing a real explosion in modding until something is done about an SDK or better modding tools. 

Anyway in summary Half-Life Alyx may have issues, some in game and some out of it, but it is still unrivaled in the VR space, and absolute 10/10 experience and a must play spinoff/sequel to the Half-Life series.

145624218.review:
i thought it was impossible, but i think i may have found a VR game to outshine saints and sinners
half life alyx is a game that ive known of its existence for quite a while, but ive never really thought about playing it because ive never played any other half life games. but then one day i was looking for VR games to play on steam and i remembered i got alyx for free when i bought my valve index. so i thought "eh, i'll give a try at least"
and i am so glad i did, because this game blew my expectations out of the water. its a really well made linear VR shooter where you traverse through the game, fighting a variety of enemies as you progress, as well as occasionally solving the odd puzzle. one of the things i like about the game was how theres a ton of things you can interact with throughout the game world. theres junk on shelves your can mess with, paintings on walls you can move around and take off the walls, knobs on sinks and tubs you can twist, ECT. sure none of these things are essential to the gameplay, but they really help with the immersion and makes it feel more like a real world. i wish more vr games did this. the game has a large variety of environments you encounter throughout your playthrough. from futuristic alien buildings, to dark dingy sewers, to overgrown abandoned houses, and more. the game has an impressive runtime, having the average casual playthrough being around 10-12 hours, which probably still isnt enough for me to consider it worth its price tag, but i got it for free so screw it.
the game also has these "gravity gloves" which are really intuitive from a VR standpoint. now most vr games can be a bit of a pain to have to bend over or crouch down to pick up everything, some games fix this by letting you "force grab" objects from a certain distance, but the gravity gloves not only solved this problem, they made it fun. you can latch onto any object from pretty much any distance, and flick your wrist to fling it right into your hand. this is done in a way that feels very natural, and enjoyable to do.
combat is pretty well done. theres a variety of enemies that you encounter, but they all require different tactics to fight. some enemies can be killed instantly if you shoot them in a very specific spot, some require to be shot in certain parts in a certain order to kill, and some you can feed explosives to for an explosive death. you have 3 weapons, a pistol, shotgun, and smg. theyre all very well balanced and you never feel like you overuse one, or one gets left out. youre also given grenades, health injectors, and explosive barrels you can shoot.
the story is pretty well done, even as someone who has never played half life before i could still understand the story perfectly fine. i think they wanted to make the game newcomer-friendly so even though they relied on pre-existing story beats from the previous games, but they still explained it for players who dont know or remember it. it had some colorful characters, both likeable and comedic, and the storyline has twists and turns that keeps you wanting to know what will happen next
overall its a great game to play if you have a VR headset. if you got it with your valve index give it a try, but if not maybe wait for a sale if youre going to buy

09/02/2023

I purchased this (Half-Life: Alyx  for $1000 and got the Valve Index VR headset/ base stations and hand controls free.  ARE YOU KIDDING ME?  NOTHING is "FREE".

Now that I got that off my chest...hahaha.  

I'm sort of new to gaming and loved it passively throughout my life.  Always wondered about VR and finally jumped in the game and loving it.  

Many gamers I'm sure have tough skins and very seasoned to take everything gaming has to offer.

Well, I tell ya, I was totally unpressed on this Half-Life: Alyx "game".  One thing that got me on this title was that fact it was solely made for VR.  How can that be?  Well, once I set up my system and was ready to go, I fell right into playing this game with both feet in the water and never turning back.  Albeit, I do take many breaks...haha.

You can almost smell the air as you're playing.  You can almost feel the presence of "whatever is lurking".  For me, being weak at heart..HAHA....it's hair raising even to the point at times I have to take off the headset, tell myself it's only a game, put the headset back on and only find myself taking it off again!  The sound track is enough for me to pull off the headset.  HAHAHAHAHAA

This game is an adventure loaded with horror as well as “break time” where you can explore the area if you want.  Even after “killing” your threat(s), there is time to explore and oh man, the DETAIL.  I found myself rearranging the boxes on shelves at times...HAAAAAA

Running your fingers over the screened windows and along the old cast iron heaters brings even more life and realisim to this game as there are details way beyond I could even imagine.  There were/are times where I forget where I am and actually wave the dust from the front of my face only to realized it's all VR.  HOLY COW! Talk about DETAIL!

The lighting is superbly done to where even in low lighted areas, you can see a light source which subtly illuminate surrounding objects even at the correct angles.  In the trains,  similar lighting is so realistic. 

Only thing I found so far, is the writers/programmers could have made a similar lighting effect for Alyx.  She has no shadow whatsoever.

I finally found this as I wondered around in the plaza to the Northern Star.  The "sun" was casting shadows all over the place, so Alyx turns around, looks down, and "NO SHADOW".    Not a deal breaker by all means, but it would have added an extra layer of realism.  

Even Friends were amazed at the relistice and detailed graphics within the game.  During my “downtime” within a segment, inside or out, I would take them on a “tour” of that portion on the game.  I had to hold their hands while the spun around...Hahaha

Overall, if you like this kind of game...THIS is the game.  (like I should know what other games do...hahaha).  I found the comments about the game to be true and spot on.  Even though I have nothing to compare this game to, I would comfortably say, this is the BEST so far. 


This game was already 3 years old at the time I started playing it, I would only imagine VR will be the way to go for certain things of course.  Can't wait to finish this one and start it all over as well as delve into other titles and genres.  

Thanks for reading.
Cheers.

145549756.review:
(REVIEW IS SPOILER-FREE!)

[u]FIRST OF ALL: ACCESSIBILITY![/u]
(because i dont see a lot of steam reviews mention it, on any game.)

[list]
[*]game difficulty can be adjusted, whether you want to play easy due to accessibility, or if you still want a bit of a challenge even if youre bad at games! 
[*]captions work great, along with great voice acting that's clear and audible. 
[*]lots of movement required. this is either an upside or downside, depending on how your body is about gettin some exercise. personally made me very achy, very fast, but thats due to my specific chronic pain issues so take it with a grain of salt
[*]big modding community so if you need somethin you can probably find a mod for it somewhere. 
[*]easy-to-learn controls, but may cause issues for those with motor skills/hand-eye coordination problems. still generally do-able though! 
[*]THE GAME CAN BE LOUD!! because theres guns explosions etc. but overall more accessible audio-wise than any other half-life game! (and most first person shooters in general, tbh)
[*]contains various common emotional and sensory triggers (blood/gore, body horror, aliens, loud audio and sudden noises, along with flashing) while none of this is new for the half-life franchise, i think its especially important to mention due to it being a VR title. stay safe, and err on the side of caution if any of this may cause you serious medical issues!
[/list]

^ ive also allowed comments on this review if anyone has other accessibility questions! comments unrelated to accessibility will be ignored, sorry!

[u]OVERALL REVIEW[/u]

quite literally the most beautiful game i've ever played. in so many ways.

in the time that it took me to finish the game over years (due to inconsistent access to vr hardware) it was always so easy to get back into it after being away for a long time. after becoming unable to properly play in the way i used to, i did NOT let that stop me from seeing the absolute gorgeous entry via watching a playthrough on youtube. while it's possible to play without vr with mods, or just watch it online, i guarantee you that they DID go to the absolute fullest when selecting virtual reality as a medium. its genuinely the best vr experience, maybe even game as a whole, known to humanity. without exaggeration. and while its enjoyable in any format you consume it in, i highly encourage use of VR equipment to play this yourself.

after seeing the ending, i woke up the next day back to being obsessed with half life like i was years ago. and now im dead set on adjusting my setup to allow me to play with vr controllers even with my disability and limited hardware from my bed. im not kidding when i say that this game is so beautiful that im finding workarounds for getting it to work on a gaming laptop with outdated hardware just so i can play it again with my disability. 

level design is intuitive, clear, and gorgeous. graphics are gorgeous. overall visual design is gorgeous. game ran great for me, with little to no framerate dropping. lots of fun with both central game mechanics AND story. heart wrenching writing that made me want to throw up from getting emotional about it. easy-to-learn gameplay that never takes long to pick up, no matter how long youve been gone.

my criticisms: jeff scared me. but seriously, the only thing i have is more of a warning that applies to vr in general. take breaks!! 1-2 hour gameplay sessions with 15 min breaks worked best for me. any longer than that and i ended up achy, nauseous, and disoriented due to the heavy action and movement present within the semi-frequent combat areas. 

10/10 game, worth every penny.

145220948.review:
Half-Life: Alyx is a monumental masterpiece that redefines the boundaries of virtual reality gaming. Valve has done the impossible by delivering an experience that not only lives up to the storied legacy of the Half-Life series but also sets an unprecedented standard for VR gaming as a whole. From the moment I put on the headset, I was transported into a world that felt so real, so engaging, and so utterly captivating that it's hard to put into words.

The attention to detail in Half-Life: Alyx is nothing short of awe-inspiring. Every corner of the game world is meticulously crafted, immersing you in a post-apocalyptic City 17 that oozes atmosphere and authenticity. The visual fidelity is breathtaking, with lifelike textures, intricate environmental design, and lighting effects that make you forget you're in a virtual space. Valve's Source 2 engine is a true marvel, and it's clear that the developers have pushed it to its limits to create an experience that pushes the boundaries of what VR can achieve.

Gameplay-wise, Half-Life: Alyx raises the bar for VR interactions. The game brilliantly leverages the immersive capabilities of virtual reality to make every action feel natural and intuitive. Picking up objects, solving puzzles, reloading weapons – it all feels incredibly satisfying. The physics-based interactions make the world feel tangible, and the level of interactivity is unmatched. Even after hours of gameplay, I found myself constantly amazed by the sheer depth of the mechanics and how well they integrate into the narrative.

Speaking of the narrative, Half-Life: Alyx delivers a gripping story that fills in the gaps between Half-Life and Half-Life 2. Players assume the role of Alyx Vance, a beloved character in the series, as she fights against the oppressive Combine forces. The writing is top-notch, filled with the kind of storytelling and character development that the Half-Life series is known for. The pacing is impeccable, seamlessly blending action-packed moments with quieter, more atmospheric segments that allow you to soak in the world around you.

One of the standout features of Half-Life: Alyx is its innovative use of VR to create tension and immersion in ways that traditional gaming cannot. The suspense of creeping through dark corridors, the rush of frantically defending yourself against enemies, and the heart-pounding encounters with terrifying creatures – all of these are heightened by the VR medium. The game's sound design and spatial audio play a crucial role in this, allowing you to hear enemies approaching from all directions and creating an uncanny sense of presence.

Valve has also shown a commitment to accessibility with Half-Life: Alyx. They've included a variety of comfort options that cater to players with different levels of VR experience, ensuring that everyone can enjoy the game without feeling overwhelmed or nauseous.

In conclusion, Half-Life: Alyx is a monumental achievement in gaming, pushing the boundaries of what's possible in virtual reality. Valve has not only delivered a worthy addition to the Half-Life series but has also set a new gold standard for VR game development. If you own a VR headset, playing Half-Life: Alyx is an absolute must. It's an experience that will stay with you long after you've put down the headset – a testament to the power of immersive storytelling and groundbreaking gameplay.

Pros:

Stunning visual fidelity and attention to detail
Innovative and intuitive VR interactions
Gripping narrative that expands the Half-Life universe
Tense and immersive gameplay unique to the VR medium
Thoughtful accessibility options for all players
Cons:

Requires a VR headset, limiting accessibility for some gamers
Verdict: Half-Life: Alyx is a true masterpiece that sets a new standard for virtual reality gaming. Valve has outdone themselves, creating an experience that's not only a must-play for Half-Life fans but a showcase of the incredible potential of VR as a storytelling and gameplay medium.

144883077.review:
This is VR the way it should be. Awesome.

While many are hopelessly waiting for valve to be able to count to 3 one day, they surprised everyone by making this stunning VR adventure/FPS in the half life universe. No Gordon Freeman in sight, but Alyx is just as good.

Built from the ground up for VR, and only playable on VR, it is a true masterpiece. The graphics are absolutely stunning. I have the luck to have a system that can run this on ultra highest settings and it is incredible. The details, not only in textures, models, but also the maps themselves, are a joy to behold.

The game guides you very nicely through the entire story. And yes, it is very very linear. You don't have many points that let you stray far from the given path, and sometimes that feels a little like a missed opportunity. Some extra rooms, corridors etc on the side would have been nice.

Cans, books, etc,  moves as you tough them. Although not everything is 'touchable' like in bonelabs/boneworks, they found a very good balance.

The biggest 'flaw' I see in this masterpiece, is that the 3 or so guns are not held on your person. And it is a dial menu that lets you select them. This is the only immersion breaking point. I would have liked to see some holsters on your person instead.

But aside that, I can completely recommend this game.

A must for pcvr FPS lovers.

143963526.review: Even years later, this is by far the best VR game available today. I've owned my Quest 2 since May 2021 and played everything from The Walking Dead to Star Wars to Beat Saber, and while others are fun experiences that allow you to explore a beloved universe in a new way, Half Life: Alyx is so much richer in just about every way I can think of. The mechanics for interacting with the environment are smooth (though not without a freeze and reload glitch here and there; this could be due to my low-spec GPU:  GTX 1650), the environments are rich and the story is engaging throughout. If you have a VR headset and a PC as capable as mine or more, you owe it to yourself to play this game in VR; there is truly nothing quite like it.

143723431.review:
Let me preface this review by saying I haven't beat it and I'm pretty sure I'm fairly far off from doing so. Usually I try to wait until I complete the initial stories of singleplayer games but I have rare exceptions. This game is amazing. 

The physics are next level in this game, nearly every object can be interacted with, objects have collision with your guns and such. It's so immersive. It's horror fairly horrific in some sections which take place in dark places where you need to use external lightsources to see. The gunplay is fun but not over the top. It's very basic, you just aim, shoot, press a button to remove mag and load the clip it, then slide the slide back to chamber a round. It's that simple but each gun has different mechanics for reloading that are easy and fluent to do. 

The story is the real outlier because it is just.. valve goodness. It is so good and well paced. Do I recommend this game? Surprisingly it's a great game to learn VR and get your VR legs in so I can safely recommend it for ANY players that play VR, new or old.

143513528.review:
"Flowerpots are quite effective against Barnacles." ~No-one but the player.

Half-Life: Alyx is, even 3 years after its release, one of the best VR games out there. It is clear that the developers went all out on this game. The story, the mechanics, the environment, the interactions, puzzles and hidden secrets make the game feel very alive.

I would consider the game more an adventure rather than a FPS. The game houses 3 different guns you can upgrade as the play the story. Unfortunatly the game has no melee wepons for you to use. Besides weapons and grenades you are equiped with a set of Gravity-Gloves, a special set of gloves that allows you to pull in items from around you. While the gloves are not as obviously usefull like a gun, they can be used in a lot of creative ways to help you, both in and out of combat.

The movent the game offers are both locomotion and teleport. Crouching is done by, well, crouching. Jumping is however, not part of the game. 

The story takes place in a city you won't travel far in. Map wise is seems like a short walk but the levels are plentyfull. On the streets,  though the building, metrostations and even further underground you will face many different environments on a play-through. The story is intense and well-paced. Everywhere you find silly humors and funny achievment challenges. 

Half-Life: Alyx is a must play for those who have a VR set. And when you do get to play the game, say hi to Jeff for me.

The only thing I can say as a reason to maybe not buy it is that this game probably isn't a good game to be playing as your very first vr game. Although it is very fun, for a first time vr title it utilizes so many advantages of the medium that, at least in my experience, it can be very jarring at times. Now when I say this I do not say it as a criticism of the game but more of a warning to familiarize yourself with VR at least a little bit with other games before you just hop right into this game is all. Other than that this game is great and if you can you should play it

143494866.review:
its 5am and i just now figured out why i couldnt open the fkn menu for the past hours of my life. IF YOURE LEFTHANDED: GUESS YA FUGGED! 

Using a pico 4, being left handed and playing this game will result in y, x, b and a no longer working, thus the menu wont even open to switch it back. And guess what, in the main menu: you cant change preferences, so the actual changes i wanted to make are now impossible. GJ valve, 3 years later and ya didnt learn shid.

edit: 
Anyway, I have found one workaround for now, which is to go to Program Files\Streaming Assistant\driver\bin\win64\RVRPlugin.ini and change controllertype=3 to controllertype=1. This makes the Pico software "emulate"/pretend the controllers to be Rift CV1 controllers (as opposed to Pico/Quest 2 controllers by default).

I think some SteamVR games can't quite handle newer generic controllers yet, so this fallback is a workaround. 

credit to https://steamcommunity.com/id/perfrigefacio 

Now that i actually got to play the game: pretty nice. obviously.

The environments actually made me paranoid again. 10/10 they really went all out and weren't kidding about this being a great VR experience. I guess this is what was happening instead of HL2 Episode 3. At least they didn't pull episodic shenanigans on me and just released a whole flippin' game. This was so good it almost made me forget about Episode 3. Almost.

143473803.review:
In 1998, Half-Life changed the gaming industry with its blend of fps gameplay and immersive worldbuilding and story.
In 2004, Half-Life 2 changed the gaming industry by using realistic simulated physics to immerse the player further into its world. 
In 2020, Half-Life: Alyx (hopefully) changed the gaming industry by proving that a AAA story-driven game like Half-Life can work in fully immersive VR.

This is probably the best looking VR title I own. While I enjoyed the game, I felt like it lacked the true half-life feel. I tried to conserve ammunition for my entire play through because I wasn't really finding it as much as you would in the older Half Life games. By the time I got to the end of the game, i was annoyed with myself that I just didn't use my weapons as much, because while ammo was still scarce, i never really had an opportunity to really use my weapons unless it was a scene with folks shooting back.

While this game looked amazing in VR, it really doesn't play like the classic Half Life games. Its still a fun play through, but I didn't feel that Half Life connection I had in the good ole' days.

143313232.review:
Half-Life: Alyx is an absolute VR gem that has redefined the possibilities of gaming in virtual reality. As a fan of the Half-Life series, stepping into Alyx's shoes was a dream come true. The attention to detail, immersive environments, and seamless gameplay mechanics left me awestruck from start to finish.

The game's narrative is gripping and seamlessly fits into the Half-Life universe, providing new insights and depth to the story. The puzzles are ingeniously designed, making use of VR to challenge both your wits and reflexes. Each encounter with enemies feels intense and strategic, pushing the boundaries of what VR gaming can achieve.

Graphically, Half-Life: Alyx is a showcase of VR capabilities. The level of realism in the world, from the smallest objects to the grandest vistas, is jaw-dropping. The sound design further enhances the immersion, with every creak and whisper adding to the suspenseful atmosphere.

Valve has truly outdone themselves with Half-Life: Alyx. It's a game that demands to be experienced by any VR enthusiast and a must-play for Half-Life fans. This is not just a game; it's a landmark achievement that sets a new standard for VR gaming. Kudos to Valve for delivering an unforgettable journey that will have you craving more.

Strongly recommend, this will be the blueprint for serious VR games in the future.

143111340.review:
"This game is a Half-Life." How many times have I repeated this phrase to myself?
Wait, Is this game really a Half-Life?
Here's my review of the game as a veteran of the Half-Life franchise (I first finished the first installment in 2003, I finished all the games on PC and consoles a lot of times).
/!\ Warning, massive spoilers.

The 13 long years of waiting for HL2:EP3 or HL3 ends with the release of a so-called prequel in VR that no one asked for.
We start with an affront to the fans, how could this end well?

Here are the few positive points that I could identify:

The game has (kinda) beautiful graphics thanks to the Source 2 engine and a pleasant physics engine.
The puzzles are well thought out although too numerous and redundant.
The weapon improvement system via "resin" is nice.
The Gravity Gloves as useful and versatile as the Gravity Gun.
The characters are charismatic, and can have a serious or humorous tone.
The music composed by Mike Morasky is appreciable, very electro and industrial, but is not as great as those of HL1 and HL2.
The sounds are very interesting, intriging, engaging and contribute to immersion.
City 17's Half-Life Alyx version is very classic, detailed, and great to look at and to explore.

But the list of negatives is quite heavy:

- Armament:
Ammo is too scarce so every bullet counts.
The enemies are too resistant compared to the weapons we have.
Only 3 weapons! I hadn't seen this since SiN Episodes: Emergence!
Some Combine Soldiers have weapons that cannot be picked up (probably because they are two-handed).

- Script
The story is too vague and has little connection to the rest of the series.
It really seems like the devs only had a vague knowledge of the lore.
Very few elements of HL2 Beta are recycled when there really is plenty to do.
The paranormal / gore side is way too exacerbated...
Where is Dog? He is supposed to protect Alyx since her childhood...
Where is Breen? Where is all the propaganda?

- Bestiary
If the bestiary is quite varied, but how to legitimize its disappearance before the events of Half-Life 2?
We had the same problem with the Race-X in Opposing Force long before...
The new enemies are not fun to fight for several reasons.
The Armored Headcrab is armored on top and only its ventral part is vulnerable.
The different Combine Heavy Soldiers are very resistant and their weapons hurt too much, even from afar. Like I said, we can't take their guns. They are similar to the Heavy Replicas from F.E.A.R. ...
The Antlion Soldiers are armored, they have to be dismembered so that you can shoot into their abdomen, causing them to explode!
Ditto for the Antlion Workers, except they spit a painful blue acid that coats the screen...
The worst of the worst from Half-Life Alyx's bestiary:
The Lightning Dog (Reviver): A kind of electric Headcrab that, in addition to electrocuting you and being resistant, can take control of corpses like the Remnant from F.E.A.R. 2 and land powerful attacks.
"Jeff": A unique, blind, but not deaf zombie. I have no words, how to say... Why does such an abomination exist in the Half-Life universe? Who could validate this stuff?

- Scenery
If the city, on the surface is pleasant, it is not the same for the undergrounds, moreover too numerous. You will become claustrophobic.
The interiors are massively covered with a kind of biomass, dirty as possible, sometimes explosive. There too, we are closer to F.E.A.R. 2 for example.
The last chapter is closer to Portal 2. What is the visual affiliation with Half-Life 2?

- Dubbing
The game is only dubbed in English! Seriously! After dubbing the old Half-Life games in loads of languages!
However, it is subtitled in a few languages, even if it's easy to understand in the original version.

- Bugs:
I found myself several times and easily outside the map not knowing where to go...
We regularly find ourselves blocked everywhere for no reason.
Sometimes I can't grab ammo because it's stuck in the floor.

- Conclusion
Half-Life Alyx is for me a HUGE disappointment, as Half-Life games are legendary.
The ending of the game clearly calls for a sequel to HL2 Episode Two.
The game being what it is, Half-Life 3 could be ruined.
Better for Valve not to make it, and let's keep its legendary aura.
In the meantime, I'm going back to Half-Life 2 Beta.

143107996.review:
The game is a technological achievement that showcases incredibly immersive VR interaction, as well as highly detailed environments with many interactive objects, despite the high performance goal.

The story occurs between the events of Half-Life 1 and Half-Life 2, within City 17. This time, you're Alyx (didn't see that coming), in a journey through Xen-infested, Combine-controlled environments, saving your father and getting to the super-weapon concealed in The Vault. The campaign is about 15 hours long, and can be extended with mods from the Workshop.

Many elements from previous Half-Life games return in this entry, to the point that some parts of the game try to exactly replicate environments from previous entries. Gnome Chompski is one such feature, but at least this time he's much easier to transport.

The combat is enjoyable and tense in some spots, and there are new and returning enemies to find, as well as many (honestly, filler) holographic puzzles, however, the story and immersive presentation are the real kicker. The audio design is also dramatically improved, and despite most returning character voice actors being new, they did a perfect job.

[hr][/hr]
Just to address a few technical things:

The NoVR mod is not worth the time, not unless the game is played in VR first. It would ruin the first experience for such a massive title where the core idea is that it's a VR game, where interactions aren't dumbed down to pressing a button, your accuracy is determined by the ability to aim with your own hands, and it is paced such that the player is expected to take a look around instead of running through levels.

The Linux version works reasonably well*, however, during my time playing the game, I always kept getting permanent lag during the session after some time. I suspect it's due to my setup. Also, playing the game may require replacing some libraries due to static linking and the libraries becoming out of date.

* On AMD, must force RADV for SteamVR and AMDVLK for the game to avoid major slowdowns.

The best example of the future of VR games. Many of the issues we've seen with motion, gun-play, world-building, and user interactions have been smoothed out with perfection here. Should other developers work with this as a template, and VR tech get more convenience and/or cheaper, VR should soon become the next phase of gameplay. 

For the game itself, it is wonderful for a Half-life fan to see the world again, the return to places like City 17 and seeing most iconic characters has made this such a wonderful callback. Excellent voice acting and a very interesting story, alongside a clear tease at how Valve might not have completely given up on the Half-life story and instead are cleverly attempting to rewrite it to fix dead-ends they'd made for themselves in the prior games. My only hope si this leads to a new full title for the series. 

My only sadness is the change to the zombie voices, I miss my  "My Icing!"

142737682.review:
for a game that is deliberately telling people that its not half life 3, and is therefore not going to be as groundbreaking has half life 3 would be, it still features great game design and use of vr's capabilities with features that wouldnt be possible in a 1st person shooter. such small and intricate spaces meant to be explored up close instead of vast open areas, seamless interaction with objects and puzzles (although they do get stale by the late game) that feels natural because of the way the hands can be controlled, and cover based shooter combat that is actually fun without being as overwhelming as an actual war.

the gravity gloves are a really good choice for the most important specific action the player preforms in the game because the average office or bedroom is of course not as large as the in game environments, so the gloves allow the player to interact with distant objects and pick things up without it being as tedious as in real life and breaking the pacing. additionally they perfectly fit into the half life universe thematically.

and even while making a soup of good game mechanics the devs didnt forget that the purpose of vr is immersion. so even though my janky computer cant handle the graphics without lagging out my quest 2 every 20 minutes i was still immersed in the beautiful environments because i find alien flesh growths beautiful. even if the game had no story and was just called explore abandoned buildings simulator ft. a hundred headcrabs i would still give it a good rating.

and that is because the story isnt the focus. its pretty simple and easy to follow on its own but in the context of having played half life 2 is probably a genius retcon type situation that solves the cliffhanger of episode 2 and creates a new one for the story of a new game to use. that being said i havent played half life 2 yet and i dont fully know how im meant to interpret the story even after watching an explanation video so i can write this review accurately.

the game doesnt have any outstanding drawbacks reducing its quality and the largest issue for me was the small amount of content and little replayability, but both of these issues can be fixed with mods which the game openly supports in the form of custom maps and addons.

so while i dont recommend spending $400 or so just to play this game (or any individual game), it is a must have for anybody that already has access to vr.

4/6
(leaning alot towards 5 though)

Cornflake Corn Cake


Prep Time:
10 mins
Cook Time:
25 mins
Cool Time:
15 mins
Total Time:
50 mins
Servings:
8

Ingredients
1 teaspoon butter to grease pan

1 large egg

1/2 cup white sugar

6 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted

1/2 cup plain yogurt

1/2 cup milk

1/2 cup cornmeal

1 cup all-purpose flour

1 teaspoon salt

1 1/2 teaspoons baking powder

1/4 teaspoon baking soda

2 1/2 cups cornflakes, divided


Directions
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease a 9-inch round cake pan generously with 1 teaspoon butter, and place a circle of parchment in the bottom. 

Whisk egg and sugar together in a bowl until light and fluffy, about 1 minute. Whisk in melted butter, yogurt, and milk until combined.

Add cornmeal, flour, salt, baking powder, and baking soda to egg mixture; whisk until dry ingredients are moistened. Fold in 2 cups of the cornflakes with a spatula. Transfer batter to the prepared pan, and smooth the top.

Scatter remaining 1/2 cup cornflakes evenly over the top; press in lightly with your fingers.

Bake in the preheated oven until a skewer inserted near the center comes out clean, about 25 minutes.

Cool cake in the pan for 15 to 20 minutes before removing to a plate. Cool completely before serving with fresh fruit or a fruit sauce.

142710218.review:
[Spoilers] Since there's so much that's good about HLA I'm going to describe the problems that mostly everyone seems to gloss over.

The story being rewritten in a short amount of time, resulting in something that's honestly very bland and could have been a lot better, the twist of it being Gman in the vault was the most obvious thing ever with no attempt to keep it a surprise, the ending being a retcon of Ep2's ending is really stupid. 
They also have a part where you watch the shadow of a lady from the cut story communicating with an Advisor, this gives the impression that she's going to be revealed later as some essential character to the plot but no, she has no relevance.

The Jeff area is cool but I personally felt it went on too long, it should have had some other segment in the middle to break it apart.
I also think Jeff has a garbage design, he just looks like a generic sc-fi humanoid monster thing, it would have been better if there was some connection to headcrab zombies incorporated in the design, something like the poison zombie from HL2 and the Gonome from Opposing Force.

The Antlion's suck, the way they walk looks stupid and the way you fight them makes you feel like your playing a rail shooter in an arcade and ruins your immersion, I'm not sure how they could have handled them but they didn't do it well.
The design of the Antlion worker also sucks, instead of using the superior design from Ep2 they went with something that mostly looks like a recolor of the normal Antlion.

Enemies are way too bullet spongy, it's insanely annoying, it takes so many head shots just to kill a grunt.

The lack of melee combat, not only that but you can't even damage enemies with props, not even head crabs, meaning if you run out of ammo you can't do anything.

I'm honestly not a fan of the arsenal, It's very small and you don't get to pick up the soldiers weapons which sucks.
I also get they wanted everything to be usable with one hand but I would have much preferred a pump shotgun.
I have astigmatism so my right eye is very blurry and makes it hard to aim since I'm right handed, so I tend to get the Laser Sight upgrade, the problem for me is that the same upgrades on different weapons are priced differently, so if I want the laser sight on the shotgun its the cheapest upgrade for only 10 resin, but on the pistol it's the most expensive for 35, kind of annoying.

There are a lot of VR games that feel hollow and just kinda meh. Half-Life Alyx is the exact opposite of those games.

Valve has really found a way to ease you into the controls and make them actually feel natural and fun to use. From the gunning down some Combine, to traversing a dank dark tunnel filled with dangers, you will always feel in control and able to deal with anything that comes your way.

The environments are top notch and always feel natural. With plenty of small nooks and crannies you will be well rewarded to do some searching in all the dark corners for resin, ammo, and the occasional med. Some of these items will just be sitting out in the open and others will be stashed away in lockers, chests, crates, and even corpses.

Overall this has been the best VR experience I have had to date and hope to see other companies be as creative as Valve has been with making Alyx.

142542982.review:
A good example of how to make a VR shooter properly, and a continuation of the Half-Life series.
But it's over-hyped. For the first half an hour it's impressive, but after that it plays just like any other shooter - not something I expected from VR. 
Shooting with your hands in games is an old idea. As they say, "Everything new is well-forgotten old".
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2837745276
'90 arcade machines had physical guns, for 2 players. NES/Famicom, PlayStation 1 had lightgun games. Time Crisis is one of the good examples. Not only is it the same principle, but it's also cheaper and better. Instead of using this expensive helmet and clunky controllers to shoot a gun with shaking hands, you get an actual physical gun to shoot things from the screen (you might buy the big screen). And it's feels great. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LSgwlemX_Oc&ab_channel=JohnRiggs
You can make it so on PC through emulators, by the way.
So why all the fuss with VR? Just make a new Valve lightgun, which will be accessible to many people because it's a very simple (cheap to produce) device, and revive the genre of lightgun shooters.

142539136.review:
This review is 3+ years late but I was thinking about this game again and I needed to jot my thoughts down.

I got a VR headset, a 1st gen Vive, originally for trying out this new, unexplored territory of virtual reality gaming and what it could offer. I played a few games, all of which were really good in their own right but had their flaws... then I played Alyx. 

Alyx absolutely [i]ruined[/i] ruined VR games for me. Not because it's bad, but because it's so unbelievably f--king amazing. Alyx makes you feel totally connected to its environment through pretty much very small detail; how guns work, how characters in person interact with you, how you as the player interact with the environment through random things you can touch, puzzles, and how you have to actually throw stuff around off shelves and scavenge for supplies, how you have to traverse the world, and so much more. When you're behind a pillar taking pot shots at a large amount of combine, or trying to find ways to slow down zombies to buy yourself time to reload or scavenge, it really feels.like you're there doing these things. The world feels real which makes it all the more wild when the world starts breaking the rules of reality.

I don't want to spoil too much but, essentially, this game takes full advantage of its medium to deliver single handedly the best VR experience pretty much ever. And it's completely spoiled me. No other VR game comes close to being as engaging as Alyx does; not even 3+ years later. And it makes all the older VR games not fun to play because you just want to recapture that same feeling of awe, wonder, and engagement that Alyx provides.

You need to play it. You just have to. But be warned it'll ruin any other VR game for you.

Years late to the review, but having finally gotten my ultra high-def wireless VR perfected with a 7900XTX and Virtual Desktop, it was time to revisit Alyx.

In short, the hype is real and reviews are true. There is simply nothing on the market like Alyx. It is THE defining VR game. To the point where... think of your favorite 10/10 VR game... and realize Alyx is still way above that scale. You cannot rate it against other VR games. It's like being 3 years old at Disneyland. An untouchable, mesmerizing, unique experience. You believe you're in it. A smile creeps across your face as the Combine death sound plays, a life-sized Vortigaunt talks to you, and a [redacted] or a [redacted] or [REDACTED] is in your face. The immersion is so far above anything else and the storytelling and pace is classic Valve. I don't know why they're so frightened of public response to HL3 because Alyx proves they haven't lost a step.

It is nearly correct to say "do not buy VR without buying Alyx". You need it. It is what VR should've been and should continue to be (and evolve from). And I'd highly recommend Virtual Desktop too if your local wifi can handle it -- makes it much more enjoyable.

142212495.review:
Half-Life: Alyx is an incredibly captivating and immersive virtual reality game that has left players in awe. The attention to detail and the level of realism achieved in the game is truly remarkable. From the stunning graphics to the intricately designed environments, every aspect of Half-Life: Alyx has been carefully crafted to create an unparalleled gaming experience.

One of the standout features of Half-Life: Alyx is its perfect blend of gameplay mechanics and storytelling. The game seamlessly combines elements of first-person shooting and puzzle-solving with a rich and engaging narrative, keeping players on the edge of their seats throughout the entire experience. The intense moments of gunfights are balanced with moments of exploration and discovery, creating a well-rounded gameplay experience that appeals to a wide range of players.

Moreover, the Gunman Contracts mod for Half-Life: Alyx adds an exciting twist to the already fantastic gameplay. This mod introduces a new level of challenge and strategy by incorporating contract-based missions into the game. Players are tasked with eliminating specific targets within a given time frame, requiring them to carefully plan their approach and make tactical decisions. The mod enhances the replayability of the game, offering new and unique experiences even after completing the main storyline.

In summary, Half-Life: Alyx is not only a technically impressive game but also a masterclass in storytelling and gameplay design. Its attention to detail, realistic visuals, and engaging mechanics make it an absolute must-play for any fan of the Half-Life series or virtual reality gaming in general. With the added excitement brought by the Gunman Contracts mod, the game becomes even more compelling and guarantees hours of thrilling gameplay.

141925524.review:
**Played it with a No VR Mod**

I can't afford a new PC or a VR headset right now, so I decided to give the No VR mod a try, and since the game was heavily discounted I wouldn't suffer too much disappointment for the price. 

And it is actually pretty nice. Yes, the mod is still unfinished, but the world and the dialogues remain the same, it is still a Valve game. Gunplay is a bit weak and enemy AI is left as it was in VR version (pretty passive), but it is still a nice experience for the price (it was like 60% off here).

I've already seen the full walkthrough 3 years ago, so there's no bad feelings here that I experience this story this way. Feels like a walking simulator with a few puzzles and shootouts here and there. I will probably experience this in VR one day, but for now I can thoroughly recommend this No VR mod for Alyx. 

Buy the game while it is still discounted, you can play the mod later when it is finished or  save some funds and buy a VR headset, whatever you choose.
