141896427.review:
[h1] By light-years λhead still the best VR game. [/h1]

But I wouldn't say it's as good as HL 1&2.

[u] Biggest cons in my opinion: [Spoiler] [/u]

[b] - Couple of weird/incomprehensible gameplay decisions. [/b]

[b] - The game is way too easy, spending time to collect resin is not absolutely necessary, because weapons are still strong enough without upgrades. [/b]

[b] - I am really disappointed about the finale, It wasn't as epic as I was hoping for, the battle against the strider was a joke - absolutely not challenging. [/b]

[b] - After around 15 years of complete radio silence about Half-Life, I've wished Valve would have risked something in terms of story. There is no storytelling about Alyx or her past, no storytelling about her family, no new storytelling about anything, just a tiny cliffhanger that is new at the end of the game. I have the feeling that Valve is so scared of the Half-Life franchise (fear of doing anything wrong), that they don't want to risk a bad new game (HL3) or risk something in the story that would create new problems. So HL:A feels like a not really necessary, squeezed in spin-off that brings no value to the story other than the last 30 seconds at the end of the game. [/b]

But in the end, a video game has to be fun, and this is what Half-Life: Alyx does great, like every other Half-Life game.

10/10
This is the most polished and detailed game I have every played. Everything is perfectly hand-crafted to add to the immersion and it truly shows the potential of VR for gaming. Every company should take this as a blueprint for how to make a proper VR experience (though of course it's not entirely necessary to match the ridiculous level of polish). Hopefully they follow up on this with another VR half-life game, because this was one of my favorite gaming experiences ever, and I want to see more games in this style, as well as the continuation to the story. 
There is one piece of criticism I want to give this game: It's a bit too easy. It throws healing items at you left and right, and it's almost impossible to run out of ammo if you pay attention to your surroundings. But it's understandable, given the experimental nature of the game, I'm sure they wanted to play it safe before going balls to the walls with the difficulty.

If you have a Vr Headset, this game is a must have. I haven't played any of the Half-Life games but this makes me want to pick them up. You'll run into some bugs, objects being flung into nothingness from explosives, hands get stuck behind something, minor clipping. 141559519.review:
Half-Life Alyx continues to be the most developed and ambitious VR game made to this day, in 2023. Across all VR platforms and the PC that exist as of right now, Valve managed to not only release a new installment 13 years after the last Half-Life title with a twist that re-wrote the end of Half-Life 2 Episode 2, but also combine everything I constantly miss about VR games - fluid gameplay in all actions with polished technical elements, all into one package.

I'm particularly fond of the Gravity Gloves, which are super quick to learn and super easy to use. It's not on a level like Half-Life 2's sandbox gameplay with it's Gravitron, but still allows for cool moves in the world. Sometimes foregrounded physical objects that you accidentally pull towards you can be the reason you get frustrated when using them, but those moments are pretty rare.
And speaking of physical objects: Every object in the world can be interacted with as you would expect in real life: Understandable, with weight, sometimes requiring two-handed actions. I found myself very often just playing around with rattling a box of matches near my ear to hear them moving in the box or just throwing and jiggling cardboard boxes around. It's a lot of fun.

The weapons serve their purpose in the world, although I would have liked to see a rudimentary melee weapon to knock down wooden slats or headcrabs, even though i can sort of understand why it is missing in the world because it can make inventory management a whole lot easier, taking away the situation Alyx is in. But a pipe you can smack something like 3 times with would've been cool nonetheless. What i dislike about the weapon selection is the pistol, which like in many VR games, takes the design of the 1911. We've had enough games that use this as a standard. Other than that, the game shifts the focus from the pistol being the main weapon to the SMG in the second half of the game with the shotgun being the weapon which is the most coolest out of them, but also the one barely used because of how few shotgun shells you find for it.
The multi-tool is cool and is also well incorporated into the game world.

The story is well-written and i liked to experience it while playing, although the connection to Half-Life 2 Episode 2 in this game makes me want to see another game in the franchise again. Normally, when people beg Valve for another Half-Life game, i often roll the eyes, but now Valve brought it up to themselves with the ending. Characters in the world are also very well designed, have amazing voice actors and body motion within the world, with the exception of Alyx' voice. Russell is normally a character i'd despise of in real life, but through the conversations i had with him, i started to like him more and more. The conversations with Eli are often only "I miss you baby" and "I can't believe it". A little bit uncanny is the Vortigaunt's mouth when speaking, since i was so used to the design in Half-Life 2.

The game world is very well designed and fun to move around in, with the only thing in it that i can't understand being the existence and placement of resin balls which are used for weapon upgrades, or the fact that there is always ammunition scattered around and on some people and ONLY the ones YOU need, which makes the feel of the world a little bit out of place. SMG rounds being found somewhere is fine, since it's a weapon actually used by someone else than you, but finding shotgun shells and pistol magazines when seemingly no one else has a weapon like it doesn't make a lot of sense to me.

But even with little logical mistakes or irritating design choices - at least in my eyes - the game is a must-have for everyone who owns a capable PC and a VR headset. The community-made campaigns, especially Levitation, are also incredibly well-made, making them the big cherry on top of your dessert. And especially in a sale for about 24 euros, which is a bit more than Blade & Sorcery or Pavlov VR outside a sale, it's totally worth it. You can also use the NoVR mod if you don't own a VR headset, in that case tho except a lot less of the impressions that VR players normally have with Half-Life Alyx.

It would have been a good game has they made any of the thousands of items you can pickup actually do something. whats the point in having metal bars when you cant hit anything with them. whats the point in having limited ammo when you cant do anything at all without it. the only time i died was when i didnt have bullets in a pistol and a head crab slow walked towards me and then latched on and slowly killed me. it was extremely dissapointing and anti climactic. i thought for sure i could at least trap it in a bucket but nah you can even do that. might as well not touch anything in the environment and just spam the stupid teleport movement to the end of the level. this game feels so worthless honestly its like if you took all the actual interaction from a vr game and replaced it with stuff to hold >.> ion wanna hold it if its worthless. you can crush a can oooo. but find a bottle filled with liquid. you cant open the bottle. you cant hurt anyone with the bottle. but you can smash it onto the floor with your hands. its such a pointless game it doesnt feel like a full half life game it feels like a glorified tech demo that just shows off that its *possible* to have good graphics in vr. everything else is just a let down. hell even bodies are lame. you can pull a body a total of 2 inches before it literally just anchors onto the ground from a random point causing you to drop it. say you do manage to get it over to the ceiling things that grab you. it will literally refuse to even interact with the corpse. half life 2 vr literally does everything this does but better and i guess uglier. avoid this game unless its on sale fr fr. even 20 feels like a steep price though.
